Now that the Washington Redskins have retired their name and logo, some wonder when Mass. high schools will do the sameMany town leaders acknowledge Native American mascots have been a source of controversy for decades. But even during this watershed moment of racial reckoning, few have made plans to change or even discuss their school mascots, despite mounting criticism from students and alumni.

Head of the Charles Regatta 2020 canceled due to coronavirus pandemicIt's the first time since 1996 that the historic October rowing event will not be held. Organizers intend to host a virtual regatta, similar to how the Boston Marathon has adapted.

Boston already has some of the nation’s worst tidal flooding — and it will get much worse, study findsBoston has had more sunny-day flooding than nearly any other coastal community in the country — and the worst is yet to come as sea levels rise.

Looking for clues to the spread of coronavirus in Mass.? Try the toiletThe Massachusetts Water Resources Authority says it will analyze the sewage from Eastern Massachusetts at the Deer Island treatment plant for telltale signs of the coronavirus.
UMass model predicts a total of nearly 8,800 Mass. coronavirus deaths in four weeks

In time of racial reckoning, Founding Fathers increasingly viewed through modern lensThe Founding Fathers are facing renewed scrutiny. “The Revolution had very little regard for the lives of Africans and Native Americans,” says playwright Miranda ADEkoje. “White supremacy is just weaved into the fabric of this country. Not recognizing the humanity of everyone, especially those whose skins were not white, is so ingrained.”

Perspective | MagazineYoung people believe activism can help. But voting? That’s a different storyIt’s absurd to think we aren’t voting in huge numbers because we’re unengaged. It's because the electoral system needs to earn our trust.

Portraits of ‘ordinary people who continue to live and survive’ at the site of police killingsKeith Morris Washington's "Black Lives . . .” is online and on view at Concord Center for the Visual Arts.

It’s been party hearty at Rhode Island’s beaches, and Raimondo is cracking downTo try to keep the virus at bay, the governor is limiting parking at two state beaches and stepping up enforcement of mask and social distancing rules.
